fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-10600].
  {panel}

Previously, Confluence displayed the space key in a link name when the user specified a link to a page in another space.

We found this incredibly useful, as it clearly indicated the location of the linked page, without the user having to define an alias to indicate the page's location in an alias.

Now, when our users enter the following link:
\[ENG:Home\]
the important space information "ENG:" disappears from the link, misleading readers to think that the page exists in the current space.

Please consider restoring the old behavior in the next point release of the product. Since my upgrade to 2.7, I have hundreds of pages in the wiki with links that are now broken when users edit them in the Rich Text editor. And when users fix the links by adding in the space key, their fixes are lost as soon as another user opens the page again in the Rich Text editor. It's proving to be a maintenance nightmare.

As an alternative, maybe you could add an optional syntax that would strip the space key, such as the following:
\[ENG::Home\]
which would indicate that the page creator does not want to display the space link.
fields.summary: Return to old practice of displaying space key in link if user does not specify alias

  {panel}

Overloaded methods are valid in the remote API specs for XMLRPC/SOAP. 
(*Update Oct 2008*:  apparently overloaded methods are *not* valid in the WSI Basic Profile 1.0 spec, see section 5.4.3 here http://www.ws-i.org/Profiles/BasicProfile-1.0-2004-04-16.html)

Several clients cannot (or will not?) handle overloaded methods - notably Adobe Flex & AIR.  ([more info|http://kb.adobe.com/selfservice/viewContent.do?externalId=tn_19276&sliceId=1] ) and as of Oct 2008, Apache CXF. 

I suggest that Atlassian simply change the method names for few overloaded methods.
This small change would allow all clients to use the Remote API without wonky workarounds (ex. modifying the WSDL by hand)

Cheers,
Timo
fields.summary: Remove overloaded method names in Remote API to increase compatibility

  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-10459].
  {panel}

StartTLS is a common option to encrypt communication between an LDAP client and the LDAP server. I know you support SSL but can not find any documentation on the StartTLS option for an LDAP server connection.

It isn't hard to add this functionality....So there is no reason you shouldn't support it in a future version.
Just have the option:

<securityProtocol>startTLS</securityProtocol>

And then in your client code detect the if this is set and make appropriate calls on the contect to start the TLS negotiation.
It is all built into the JNDI.
fields.summary: LDAP connection supports StartTLS

[See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-10437]. {panel} If you have a heading tag (eg "h2. My Heading") directly after a bullet point with no blank line, then the heading is included as part of that bullet point (
    list item). This behaviour makes sense for plain text on the next line, but having a heading on the next line could be construed to signify a break from the list. eg: * Point 2 h2. Final heading Gee, I hope my heading wasn't indented. produces the following HTML:
  • Point 2

    Final heading

    Gee, I hope my heading wasn't indented.

    • This behaviour is inconsistent with the behaviour when a heading tag follows some plain text. In this case, the paragraph tag

    will be concluded before the heading tag

    is started. eg: h2. Here is a heading I just have some text. h2. Here is another Heading. Some text with a blank line produces this HTML:

    Here is a heading

    I just have some text.

    Here is another Heading.

    Some text with a blank line

    see example at http://extranet.atlassian.com/display/~mlassau/Test+Heading+after+Bullet+Point+List I realise the workaround is simple, and there is a bunch of other formatting tags where it is less clear whether you should finish the
  • tag, but I found the inconsistency confusing.

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-10428].
  {panel}

If I create an EventListener plugin and listen for AttachmentViewEvent.class, when the event comes in I have no way of figuring out any of the following context details:

* HTTP Session ID
* Authenticated User
* Browser User Agent
* URL
* Query String
* Referrer
* Remote IP
* Forwarded For (HTTP Header)
* (everything you get to via HttpServletRequest really)

What would be ideal is if the HttpServletRequest could be tacked onto the Event so that this detail could be logged. If a WebWork action was being used to serve the resource (like the rest of Confluence uses) we would already have access via the same mechanism used there using ServletActionContext.getRequest(). It would also give plugin authors more flexibility in that regard too!
fields.summary: Event Listeners listening to AttachmentViewEvent can't find out the username / context / session

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-10354].
  {panel}

In the default Tomcat distribution, and JIRA Standalone, there is a commented-out AJP connector:

{code:xml}
        <!-- To connect to an external web server (typically Apache) -->
        <!-- Define an AJP 1.3 Connector on port 8009 -->
        <!--
            <Connector port="8009" 
              enableLookups="false" redirectPort="8443" protocol="AJP/1.3" />
          -->
{code}

This has been removed from Confluence Standalone.

I think it should be re-added (perhaps using port 8010 to avoid conflicts with JIRA), since AJP is a) required for connecting to IIS, b) the simplest way to get SSL working, c) regaining traction now that mod_proxy_ajp is bundled with major distributions.
fields.summary: Include commented-out AJP connector in Confluence Standalone distribution

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-10253].
  {panel}

Instead of just 'watching' a page yes/no, allow more flexibility in how a user interacts with a page:  I grouped these both together because they seem like similar 'cron'-based page notification events.

- set a reminder
-- click 'remind me', enter a date and time. An email notification is sent at that date and time with a URL to that particular content. Reminder has nothing to do with the watch status. 
-- (optionally, allow other email addresses to be submitted, in a 'trusted' environment')

- snooze an actively changing page
-- after responding to a page change notification, click 'snooze'. set a date and time. All 'change notifications' for that page (for that user) will be postponed until after that snooze date. On the snooze date, the user will either get a single notification with a complete change long for that content, or nothing if nothing has changed. After the snooze period, the watch status returns to normal. 
-- (optionally, allow ALL notifications to be surpressed. this would be used to spare co-authors from an email barage if you know you are going to make dozens of edits in the next few hours.)
fields.summary: Set 'Page Reminders' and 'page snooze'

To keep the child pages unique, this process would need either to automatically prepend a predefined string (i.e., PCBET_ in my example) to the new child pages or have the ability to enter it (either each one individually or one prefix for all) at the time of creation.

Example

Child2
Child3

In the global theme configuration screen, the "Default Theme" means the standard state-of-the-art look and feel that Confluence ships with.  I'll refer to that as the "Standard Theme" in this description.
In the space theme configuration screen, the "Default Theme" is correctly described as "the globally configured look and feel."  Unfortunately, if the global theme is not configured to the Standard Theme, then a space cannot be configured to use that theme.

To replicate:

1) Set the global theme to 'Confluence Classic Theme'
2) Set the space theme to 'Confluence Classic Theme'. This configuration works.
3) Switch the space theme to 'Default Theme'. The space appears similar to the Classic Theme.

  {panel}

Confluence external links to attachments are very difficult to use because they require knowledge of arbitrary page IDs.

Example:

http://confluence.atlassian.com/download/attachments/133726/view.gif?version=1

It should be more meaningful, for instance when accessing an attachment in  "Home" page of the "DevTalk" wiki space

http://confluence.atlassian.com/download/attachments/DevTalk/Home/view.gif?version=1

Also,  this kind of link naming is better so that you can remove the filename part, you get the page where the attachment is residing in.

  {panel}

The edit popups for font color and emoticons are unusable because the content is offset inside the popup and mostl if not all is clipped out, and the popup is not resizeable. If I can't use the font color popup, that feature is useless; likewise emoticons.

Looks like a few FF extensions are causing the problem...

most - No Squint
also - Live PageRank
Stylish

When these are both removed, the problem goes away. 

Overall, I am unable to get the full effect of either the emoticon popup (all emoticons pushed off the page, just a sliver showing) or the font color popup (more than half the colors clipped). These give partial effects when I enable and disable them.

These three FF extensions are definitely an issue with Confluence popups, especially the emoticons, but also the font color. I know it may be their problem, not yours. I will probably keep them disabled, as none of them is utterly crucial to me. Luckily, the really important extensions seem ok.
fields.summary: FireFox extension create havoc with edit popups wrong size, offset, unresizeable -- for font color and emoticons
